windows.symptom: Encrypting File System (EFS) and Windows Hello        Does anyone know how EFS certificates are secured when using Windows Hello with an account? I was under the impression that the EFS private key was secured by encrypting it with the password. However on an account with Windows Hello enabled, logging in using Windows Hello (using biometrics instead of the password) still allows you to access EFS encrypted files. I was expecting that the first time I logged in, I would have needed the password and only then onward I should have been able to unlock the session using Windows Hello.
solutions: Hi my name is Ross, I'm an independent advisor. I'd be happy to help with your issue.It’s designed to work seamlessly with windows hello, so once authenticated you don’t need to re-authenticate to decrypt your EFS files.I’ve linked to an article which gives some further background information on EFS:https://www.thewindowsclub.com/encrypting-file-...Regards, Ross Note: This is a non-Microsoft website. The page appears to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the site that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the site before you decide to download and install it.

Hi Ross! That didn't really answer my question. My question was *how* is the private key kept secure. Please refer to the diagram https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encrypting_File_System#/media/File:EFSOperation.svg. My question is how is the "user private key" shown in the diagram stored and decrypted by Windows when using Windows Hello. Previously I assumed this was encrypted using the user password. However, if the user's private key is available just with a finger scan, how is it secured?

It’s stored in the Windows certificate store, which is secured on a per user basis. I.e. it is only available once a user has been authenticated.In this scenario it makes no difference whether a user has logged in with a password of Windows hello. As at the point of login the keys are now available to the user.

Okay, in that case, what is it secured with? What is the private key encrypted with in the certificate store? Or is it kept in plain text, but just not accessible till the user authenticates?It’s stored in the Windows certificate store, which is secured on a per user basis.

I’m not sure if the exact mechanism but I can point you in the direction of the API’s which are used by the certificate store and the many (many ...) pages of documentation and certifications it supports:https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/...Regards,Ross

windows.symptom: Frequent Crashes while Gaming        Hello, I've been having problems with either my game or computer crashing while playing the game League of Legends (and it's various game modes) quite a bit recently and I'm at my wits end. Everything points to some kind of driver being broken but I don't have a clue which.Here is a folder with all the mini crash dumps. I have a full crash dump available as well if needed.https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Xmrs3ImrrVmtF0_LaLbfH0kxWtuCSUI5
solutions: Hello Keiuran, I am Andrew an independent advisor. I've looked through your dump files, thank you so much for that. I've seen a lot of IRQL errors, buffer overrun errors and straight memory corruption errors. I'm going to ask you to test your RAM first.On the search bar search for mdsched.exe Run this and come back with the results. It may take a while to test. After results come in you can also test and repair the system files for the IRQL errors I noticed.In the search bar, type cmd. Right-click on cmd.exe and select Run as Administrator. Type SFC /scannow and press the Enter key. Re-enter Command Prompt as Administrator and run these: dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /scanhealth dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /restorehealth dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /startcomponentcleanup Take Care Keiuran, we'll fix this. Andrew

Memory scan completed two passes without any issue.C:\WINDOWS\system32>SFC /scannowBeginning system scan.  This process will take some time.Beginning verification phase of system scan.Verification 100% complete.Windows Resource Protection did not find any integrity violations.C:\WINDOWS\system32>dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /scanhealthDeployment Image Servicing and Management toolVersion: 10.0.18362.1Image Version: 10.0.18362.418[==========================100.0%==========================] No component store corruption detected.The operation completed successfully.C:\WINDOWS\system32>dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /restorehealthDeployment Image Servicing and Management toolVersion: 10.0.18362.1Image Version: 10.0.18362.418[==========================100.0%==========================] The restore operation completed successfully.The operation completed successfully.C:\WINDOWS\system32>dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /startcomponentcleanupDeployment Image Servicing and Management toolVersion: 10.0.18362.1Image Version: 10.0.18362.418[=====                      10.0%                          ][==========================100.0%==========================]The operation completed successfully.I have previously run these besides the startcomponentcleanup less than a week ago.dism.log has been put in folder.

windows.symptom: Blue screen error        I have a persistent blue screen error and all efforts to login to windows 10 have failed. I have tried the safe mode, resetting, restarting etc nome has worked, i don’t know what to do.
solutions: Hi Nicholas Since none of the options in the Recovery Environment are working for you, your best option is to create bootable Windows 10 installation media on another PC and then use that to try to repair your PC, by booting form that drive . . .Click this link: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-downlo...to download the Media Creation Tool (Click on Download Tool Now), with that you can download the latest Windows 10 ISO (Select Create Installation Media for Another PC), you can create a bootable USB flash drive (min 8GB) using that toolThen, Boot your PC from the Installation Media you just created (change Boot Order in your BIOS) then choose 'Repair this Computer'

windows.symptom: WiFi turns off when I wake my computer from sleep        Hi! So a few months ago I got a new Windows 10 computer, but this issue started a while after. When I wake my computer from sleep, the WiFi for the entire house shuts off for up to 30 minutes. I’m using an ethernet cable. I’m not 100% sure, but I believe this problem started happening when my brother also connected an ethernet cable from his Windows 10 pc to our router. I’ve tried changing various internet settings, but I still can’t solve this problem. If you have a solution, let me know! Thanks!
solutions: Hi EP. I'm Greg, an installation specialist, 10 year Windows MVP, and Volunteer Moderator here to help you.Are you using a router or at least a switch which is required to connect more than one ethernet cable most modems?Turn off both Modem and router/switch, wait 10 minutes then restart the modem, wait 5 minutes then restart the router or switch.Try resetting the router if applicable: https://www.lifewire.com/resetting-a-home-netwo...I can give you steps to troubleshoot ethernet in Windows 10 but from what you say it's almost certainly caused by the way the second ethernet cable was attached.Let me know what you find, and any more information you have to add about how it's set up and what has been done.______________________________________________ Standard Disclaimer: There are links to non-Microsoft websites. The pages appear to be providing accurate, safe information. Watch out for ads on the sites that may advertise products frequently classified as a PUP (Potentially Unwanted Products). Thoroughly research any product advertised on the sites before you decide to download and install it.

Hi EmeraldParrot,you must try to isolate the problem: temporarily disconnect the network cable of your brother's PC and any other device from the router, stay connected only with your PC, then restart the router and try to connect both wirelessly and via LAN.Does your pc's wi-fi work well even when you wake up from sleep?

windows.symptom: Windows 10 CPU Usage 100%        Hi!I have been having problems with my CPU usage. It's always 100%, but nothing is running in the background. When I open Task Manager, the percentages jump up and down really weirdly. Once there is Task Manager using 70% of CPU, one second later it goes back down... Then comes like Discord on the top with again 50% CPU usage and again sec later it jumps back down... like It's constantly doing this with different programs like: System, System Interrupts, Chrome, Desktop Windows Manager...
solutions: Hi Vintpüss, I'm Roshan V S, Windows expert and a Windows user like you. I appreciate you for providing details about the issue and we are happy to help you.Try the following methods : Method 1: Disable Superfetch 1. Open Taskmanager, click “More details,” then click “CPU” to order processes by how much CPU they’re using.2. Press Win+R, type "services" 3. then in the Services window scroll down to Superfetch. 4. Right-click Superfetch, click Properties, then in its Properties window click the drop-down next to “Startup type,” click “Disabled,, and OK.Method 2: Reset Your Power Plan 1. Type "power plan" into the Start search bar. 2. Then click “Choose a power plan.” 3. If you’re on “High performance” or “Power Saver,” then switch to “Balanced.” 4. For extra certainty, click “Change plan settings,” then on the new screen click “Restore default settings for this plan.”Method 3: Disable Third-Party Antivirus Software Our view here is that if you’re using antivirus software on Windows 10, then you’re probably putting unnecessary strain on your CPU (particularly if its older). It doesn’t usually hurt to have the extra security, but you probably don’t need it.So don’t be afraid to disable your third-party antivirus software to see if it helps your CPU usage. If it does, then uninstall it, because Windows Defender should really have you covered.Do get back to us with the result. We will be glad to help if you need further assistance.Regards Roshan V S Independent Advisor

windows.symptom: NVIDIA Display 26.21.14.3200 for AMD RX card ?        I don`t understand, but can anybody explain why is windows update downloading and installing this Nvidia update whereas no component in my PC requires Nvidia drivers. The GPU I am using is RX 470. I mean like, not everyone has unlimited internet why is Windows wasting our data?
solutions: I came looking for an answer to the same question. I have a Radeon ATI and Windows is pulling down the same NVIDIA driver AND an AMD Radeon HD 5450 driver.

Good question. The only thing I can think of is if you had an Nvidia gpu previously and the drivers were notfully uninstalled. To do this it's good practice to use DDU to uninstall graphics drivers as it will delete Registry keysthat uninstalling via Windows tends to leave behind, and these could trigger WU to do an update.Display Driver Uninstaller Download version 14.1.0.0Or.... use Driver Fusion...Treexy | Download free driver and device software- Best option is to disable driver updates from WU altogether. Nvidia and AMD both recommend downloading the driver,uninstalling and installing the new driver manually for best results.radeon-rx-400-series/radeon-rx-470- With an HD5450 the last WHQL update was 2015, but I doubt any 'update' WU does would benefit a gpu of this vintage.AMD Graphics Drivers HD5450Block driver updates....Enable or Disable Driver Updates in Windows Update in Windows 10 | Tutorials- I used this method when first upgrading to Win10, but don't know if it still works(It wasn't temporary, or I've forgotten I used the Registry hack along the way).How to temporarily prevent a Windows or driver update from reinstalling in Windows 10.

I don`t understand, but can anybody explain why is windows update downloading and installing this Nvidia update whereas no component in my PC requires Nvidia drivers. The GPU I am using is RX 470. I mean like, not everyone has unlimited internet why is Windows wasting our data?

windows.symptom: Dual Windows 10 boot        I have one PC with two SSD disks. On one is Windows 10 with UEFI connected to our company network and it is fully secured and closed for any changes due to strict security policies of the company and connected to their wired LAN.I would like to have another Windows 10 installed on the second SSD and connected to the same motherboard and use the different network - public WiFi in this case.Please tell me is that possible to do and is this new Windows 10 able to somehow corrupt the original company Window 10 - which I would like to avoid of course.I just want to have two complete separate Windows 10 installations and able to safety chose from which one to boot.
solutions: Hi DraganPopovic1 Yes, you can do this, basically you just want to create a Windows 10 dual boot PC with separate versions of Windows 10 on each SSD . ..So you need to download and create bootable Windows 10 installation media on a USB drive, then just install Windows 10 on the second SSDThat will create a bootloader that will give you the option of booting to either OS when you start up your PCThere is no fear of one operating system corrupting the other, by dual booting Windows 10 . . .

solutions: Hi, markburton1 My name is Smith and I am an Independent Advisor. I would be happy to help you today.I recommend you check these methods to repair any Windows problem. Press the Start key and type the word CMD, right click on the command prompt and select Run as administrator, enter the following commands one by one followed by the Enter key:•- DISM.exe /Online /Cleanup-image /Scanhealth •- DISM.exe /Online /Cleanup-image /Restorehealth •- DISM.exe /online /cleanup-image /startcomponentcleanup •- sfc /scannow https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/947821...Hope this helps. Reregister Cortana Windows Key+X > Click Powershell (Admin) > Copy the below and paste into Powershell > Enter > Reboot your computerGet-AppXPackage -Name Microsoft.Windows.Cortana | Foreach {Add-AppxPackage -DisableDevelopmentMode -Register "$($_.InstallLocation)\AppXManifest.xml"}2. solutions: Hello! My name is Marco, I am an Independent Advisor. I will do my best to help you.If you don’t see the battery icon in the panel of hidden icons, right-click your taskbar and select “Taskbar Settings.”Scroll down in the Settings window that appears and click “Turn system icons on or off” under Notification area.Locate the “Power” icon in the list here and toggle it to “On” by clicking it. windows.symptom: Getting error while Windows 10 feature update        I m having Windows 10 on (Inspiron 11 - 3148) While updating it for a Feature update I get below error :• Feature update to Windows 10, version 1903 - Error 0x80070002There were some problems installing updates, but we'll try again later. If you keep seeing this and want to search the web or contact support for information, this may help: (0x80070057)Please advise
solutions: Hi,My name is Gary an independent advisor and I would be happy to help you out with your concern,Open cmd by searching "cmd" on the start menu, make sure to run it as administratorExecute this command on the command promptDISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealthRun these commands on the command prompt to restart windows update servicesnet stop bitsnet stop cryptsvcnet stop wuauservnet stop msiserverRen C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution SoftwareDistribution.oldRen C:\Windows\System32\catroot2 Catroot2.old net start bitsnet start cryptsvcnet start wuauservnet start msiserverAfter successfully executing the commands, I would suggest performing a clean boot to disable third party background services that may be interrupting with the windows update services1. Go to start menu/search msconfig2. On the system configuration window go to the services tab3. Tick on hide all microsoft service so that this won't be affected4. Choose to disable all services5. Next, go to the startup tab and on the window choose to open task manager6. Choose to disable each applications from starting up when computer is booting up7. Close task manager and hit apply then ok8. A prompt to restart the computer will show up, choose to restartThis should restart the computer with minimal third party services starting up right after windows boots up. Once the system boots up. After this, try to update again.In the event that it still fails, I would suggest performing an in-place upgrade, this process overrides the system files which would fix corruptions or damages within the system files/packages while updating the system to the latest version of windows 10.To perform an in-place upgrade, 1. Open this link https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-downlo...2. Select Download tool, and select Run. You need to be an administrator to run this tool.3. On the License terms page, if you accept the license terms, select Accept.4. On the What do you want to do? page, select Upgrade this PC now, and then select Next.5. After downloading and installing, the tool will walk you through how to set up Windows 10 on your PC.6. When Windows 10 is ready to install, you'll have an option to keep your personal files and apps, keep personal files, or to keep nothing during the upgrade7. The process would take a while and may consist of multiple reboots. Make sure that there won't be interruption within the process to make sure that everything would sort everything outLet me know how it goes. :)

Thanks so much for the response.  I got an error while running the tool ==> DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth.Deployment Image Servicing and Management toolVersion: 10.0.16299.15Image Version: 10.0.16299.967[==========================100.0%==========================]Error: 0x800f081fThe source files could not be found.Use the "Source" option to specify the location of the files that are required to restore the feature. For more information on specifying a source location, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=243077.The DISM log file can be found at C:\WINDOWS\Logs\DISM\dism.log
